title-group.article-title: Buccinator Myomucosal Flap for Reconstruction of Glossectomy Defects

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Otorhinolaryngology–Head and Neck Surgery, Gyeongsang National University, Jinju, South Korea

sec.title: Objective
sec.p: The use of the myomucosal flap from the buccinator muscle is a valuable reconstruction method for intraoral defects. We report the clinical advantages and pitfalls of using the buccinator myomucosal flap for tongue reconstruction after intraoral resection of tongue cancer.

sec.title: Study Design
sec.p: Prospective study.

sec.title: Setting
sec.p: University hospital.

sec.title: Subjects and Methods
sec.p: We used buccal artery–based buccinator myomucosal flaps for tongue reconstruction in 11 partial or total edentulous patients who underwent resection of tongue cancer. The size and site of the tongue defect ranged from one-third to one-half of the tongue in the lateral border. We analyzed the clinical features and oncologic and functional outcomes to define adequate indications.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: All flaps were successfully harvested and transposed, and the donor sites were primarily closed. The pedicles were safely divided 2 to 3 weeks postoperatively. In 8 of 11 patients, concurrent upper neck dissection was performed without compromising blood supply to the flap. The range of tongue motion and the volume of the reconstructed tongue were satisfactory, and the patients experienced no difficulties in swallowing or speech.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Particularly in edentulous patients, the buccal myomucosal flap can be a good option for reconstructing partial tongue defects after cancer surgery.

body.p: Oral cavity defects resulting from oncologic resection can be reconstructed using several methods, depending on the size and site of the defect. Radical resection of malignant tongue tumors may lead to severe morphologic and functional defects.1-12 Currently, extensive resections involving the tongue are usually approached using free flaps, which provide the best results in terms of form and function.13,14 Small defects are primarily sutured or left alone for natural healing.

Although free flaps are considered the best option for tongue defects, the use of free flaps is also accompanied by several disadvantages in terms of donor site morbidity; the need for lengthy, complex surgery; and the replacement of oral mucosa with skin-lining tissue.

Intraoral mucosa is distinguished by mucus production with a high cell renewal rate and minimal scar formation. Buccinator myomucosal flap use was originally introduced to repair small mucosal defects of the oral cavity and in the neck region.15,16 Although the buccinator myomucosal flap has the advantage of restoring the mucosal lining over the defect, use of the buccinator myomucosal flap for reconstruction after partial glossectomy is not widespread.

An anatomic study on the buccinator muscle was published by Zhao et al in 1999.17 The buccinator muscle is a thin, quadrilateral muscle in the cheek. It originates from the outer surfaces of the alveolar processes of the maxilla and mandible. Posteriorly, it arises from the pterygomandibular raphe. Anteriorly, it inserts into the orbicularis oris muscle. Laterally, it is related to the ramus of the mandible, the masseter and medial pterygoid muscles, the buccal fat pad, and the buccopharyngeal fascia. Medially, it is covered by the submucosa and mucosa of the cheek. It forms part of the pharyngeal-buccal-orbicularis sphincter system and functions to facilitate whistling, sucking, propelling food during mastication, and voiding the buccal cavity.18

The muscle is supplied with blood through the facial artery, which enters the face and courses on the surface of the buccinator. The buccal artery, a branch of the internal maxillary artery, also supplies the muscle. The buccal artery with a neurovascular pedicle posteriorly supplies the buccinator muscle (Figure 1).

caption.p: Anatomic relationship with the buccinator myomucosal flap. Ba, buccal artery; Fa, facial artery; Ib, inferior branch of facial artery; Io, infraorbital artery; nvp of pbf, neurovascular pedicle of posteriorly based flap; Pd, parotid duct; Pb, posterior branch of facial artery; Ma, maxillary artery.

body.p: The venous drainage departs from the buccal and facial artery around the oral commissure, courses along the posterior end of the buccal muscle, and drains into the pterygoid plexus and the internal maxillary vein through the buccal vein (concomitant to the buccal artery). Finding the course and drainage of the buccal artery and vein is useful for harvesting the flap and for vascular pedicle dissection.

Other investigators had previously presented reconstruction of the tongue using a buccinator myomucosal flap based on the facial artery.16 However, this flap had a limitation in neck dissection patients because neck dissection had the potential to cause damage to the facial artery. Therefore, we use a buccinator myomucosal flap based on the buccal artery for tongue reconstruction after tongue resection with neck dissection.

We describe a procedure that uses the buccinator myomucosal flap for partial tongue defects in partial or total edentulous patients on a pedicled blood supply based on the buccal artery. Herein, the detailed surgical technique and subjective and objective outcomes (mouth opening, speech, swallowing, volume of the flap, and mobility of the tongue) in our case series are presented.

sec.title: Subjects
sec.p: This prospective clinical study was approved by the Institutional Review Board, Gyeongsang National Medical School, Jinju, Korea. Between January 2010 and December 2010, 11 partially edentulous patients with squamous cell carcinoma underwent reconstruction of partial glossectomy defects (the tongue defect was not more than half and did not extend to the floor of the mouth) using buccinator myomucosal flaps (Table 1). The patients’ ages ranged from 49 to 82 years. Reconstruction was performed immediately after resection in all patients. Two or 3 weeks after surgery, the pedicle of each buccinator myomucosal flap was divided with an ultrasonic dissector. All patients were followed up for at least 12 months (mean, 18 months).

caption.p: List of tongue cancer patients, sites, tumor staging, surgical procedures, and complications.

fn.p: Abbreviations: AWD, alive with disease; NED, no evidence of disease; PG, partial glossectomy; RT, radiation therapy; SND, selective neck dissection.

sec.p: Twelve months after the surgery, mouth opening, speech, swallowing, tongue mobility, and flap volume were evaluated. For mouth opening, the preoperative and postoperative (after 12 months) vertical lengths were compared. The length was calculated between the upper and lower incisors. The speech evaluation included a sentence articulation test to identify correct and incorrect consonant articulation. The articulation test involved a standard clinical procedure using the Fisher-Logemann Test of Articulation Competence.19 This test can be used as a screening and diagnostic tool of articulatory errors and consisted of a picture and sentence test. Results were compared with patients’ scores both before and after surgery. Evaluation of the swallowing function was based on patient interviews conducted 12 months after surgery. Parameters reported by patients were assigned a score ranging from 0 to 10. The range of tongue lateral motion was compared between the normal side and the flap side. When the tongue mobility in the normal side was assumed as 100%, the flap tongue mobility was calculated as a percentage of normal tongue mobility. The flap volumes were recorded at 1 month and 12 months postoperatively by neck computed tomography (CT) scan. The length, width, and height were measured by neck CT scan and the flap volume was calculated. (Flap volume = π/6 × length × width × height.)

sec.title: Surgical Procedure
sec.p: The transposition of the flap was planned as illustrated in Figure 2. Selective neck dissection was done (levels I, II, and III). The margins of the flap were drawn with a surgical pen, taking care to avoid the parotid duct opening at the flap’s superior margin (Figure 2). The shape and size of the flap depended on the shape of the tongue, which had been resected. The anterior limit was the oral commissure and the posterior limit was the pterygomandibular raphe. The inferior limit of the flap depended on what operation was planned. In our cases, the distance between the superior and inferior margin of the flap was not more than 4.0 cm; therefore, the donor site defect could be primarily sutured.

caption.p: The shape and size of the flap depended on the shape of the tongue, which had been resected (arrow: parotid duct).

sec.p: After incising the buccal mucosa and muscle along the upper and anterior borders, the flap was elevated generally in an anterior to posterior direction. The flap was elevated in the loose areolar plane between the buccinator muscle and the buccopharyngeal fascia. The neurovascular pedicle was identified. Dissection continued inferiorly and laterally and lower and posterior incisions were made, and then the flap was elevated (Figure 3).

caption.p: The harvested flap was sutured to the tongue and primary closure was performed at the donor site (arrow: neurovascular pedicle).

sec.p: The neurovascular pedicle was dissected from the surrounding tissues. Ordinarily, the buccal artery and vein were included in this flap, thus requiring more careful dissection. The harvested flap was sutured to the tongue, and primary closure of the donor site was carried out. Two or 3 weeks after the surgery, the pedicle was clipped and carefully examined by Doppler. After that, we divided the pedicle with ultrasonic scissors (harmonic scalpel) under local anesthesia. Twelve months after surgery, only a linear scar remained at the donor site, and the tongue motion was good (Figure 4).

caption.p: Twelve months after surgery, the linear scar was excised at the donor site and the viability of the buccinator myomucosal flap was good.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: All flaps were harvested and transposed successfully. The buccal artery and vein composed a vascular pedicle and supplied the buccinator flap. In these patients, there were no local tumor recurrences and no problems with mastication, oral competence, or facial nerve function. Eight patients experienced concurrent neck dissection (Table 1).

All patients were followed up for at least 12 months (mean, 18 months), and oral functions were assessed. Eleven patients returned to nearly preoperative stages of mouth opening. However, 1 patient had a partial limitation in mouth opening (Table 2). In speech and swallowing, all patients returned to nearly normal levels within 1 month after pedicle division. There were no differences between speech and swallowing preoperatively and speech and swallowing 12 months later. The mobility of the reconstructed tongue was also compared with the normal side. When the tongue mobility on the normal side was assumed as 100%, the flap side mobility was approximately 80%. In addition, the flap volume at 12 months postoperatively was found to have decreased to 10% to 40% of the volume at 1 month postoperatively (Table 2). However, the tongue was covered by oral mucosa; thus, the contracture was not advanced.

fn.label: a
fn.p: Flap volume = π/6 × length × width × height.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The use of intraoral local flaps harvested from the internal cheek area has been introduced in recent literature.20-22 The advantages of such flaps include the amount of tissue available, the ability to replace mucosa with mucosa, the elimination of the need for an external incision, reduced donor site morbidity, and optimal functional and cosmetic results.23 For these reasons, moderately sized defects represent a major reconstructive challenge, the main goals of which are to restore the internal oral lining, preserve or improve the function of residual structures, replace the mucosa with tissues having similar features, and obtain the best aesthetic result possible. The use of local myomucosal flaps harvested from the cheek area is one of the best means of achieving these objectives.22

The buccinator myomucosal flap, one of the intraoral local flaps introduced by Zhao et al17 in 1999, represents a useful, versatile technique for correcting defects in any part of the oral cavity with good results and minimal morbidity. This flap is similar to lingual tissue, consisting of thin, pliable mucosa capable of mucus production, with a high cell renewal rate and minimal scar formation, as well as excellent color, contour, texture match, and buccinator muscle fibers over the flap’s entire length, providing tongue muscle reconstruction without a conspicuous donor site. In the past, these flaps were used primarily for reconstruction of cleft palate defects.21

In this study, we use the buccinator myomucosal flap based on the buccal artery and vein. The buccinator myomucosal flap could be applied for tongue defects due to tongue cancer that require a neck dissection; however, Zhao et al16 did not recommend the buccinator myomucosal flap when the facial artery and vein were invaded by cancer. The buccinator myomucosal flap supplied by the buccal artery is then suitable for N0 to N1 neck disease24 because it would not be affected by the upper neck node dissection where commonly the facial artery and vein are sacrificed to eradicate the metastatic nodes in the submandibular area. In our series, concurrent neck dissection was performed in 8 patients, including level Ib dissection. The flap was not compromised because its blood supply came from the buccal artery.

The buccinator myomucosal flap is known to be optimal in edentulous patients20,24,25 because the absence of tooth elements eliminates the need for postoperative forced mouth opening that is usually used to avoid flap pedicle injuries during mastication, without patient discomfort. In our series, we employed this flap in partially edentulous patients to avoid the possibility of the patient biting the pedicle; however, we believe that this flap can also be used in dentate patients if the patient is in good compliance not to bite the pedicle until the pedicle is divided. In fact, we have experience using this flap in a dentate patient, and he recovered without any complications (data not shown).

Regarding the buccinator myomucosal flap’s donor site, its very low morbidity has been one of its main advantages,16,18,22,26 due to the possibility of closure with a direct suture or through advancement of the buccal fat pad. Of the patients in this study, 1 of 11 patients experienced trismus, and this patient was 1 of 6 who received adjuvant radiation therapy. This allows for optimal functional and cosmetic recovery, confirming the major role played by this flap in the reconstruction of moderate-size defects following tongue resections.27 The aesthetic results were excellent in all patients, without external scars or cheek depressions.

If the distance between the superior and inferior margin of the flap is more than 4 cm, skin grafting may be needed. If more tissue is needed, the parotid duct can be replanted. Finally, to improve tongue mobility and mouth opening, the flap pedicle is usually sectioned between 2 and 4 weeks after surgery under local anesthesia.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: The use of the buccinator myomucosal flap is a very good option for reconstructing moderately sized (one-third to one-half) oral cavity defects, because of its versatility, the short operating time required for the procedure, the possibility of using tissue with mucosa, and low donor site morbidity. Accompanying node dissection of level Ib is not a contraindication to this flap because this flap receives a blood supply from the buccal artery.
